About the Serena ChangeMan Merge Tool

The Serena ChangeMan Merge Tool compares text-based workfiles or revisions with a common base file, accepting or rejecting the differences between them, and combining the changes into a new file.

NOTE You cannot compare or merge binary files.

Merging is useful when you have parallel development. It enables you to combine the work performed on a branch of development and integrate it back into the main line of development.

Windows: Version Manager for Windows can perform N-way (unlimited) merges. Although you can select only three files (one base and two branch files) from within Version Manager, you can perform an N-way merge once the Serena ChangeMan Merge Tool is launched. For information on how to perform N-way merges, please see the Serena ChangeMan Merge Tool online help.

UNIX: Version Manager for UNIX can perform two-way (a base file and a branch file) merges. N-way merges are not supported on UNIX.

What You Can Merge

You can merge:

  • A revision with a workfile

  • Revisions within a single versioned file

  • Revisions in different versioned files

  • Workfiles

Considerations

When merging files, consider the following:

  • The base file is the file to use as your point of reference. This is usually the branch point--the revision from which a branch begins (typically off the main trunk of development).

  • If you are merging revisions that are located in different branches or versioned files, the base file you select should be the revision or file that is the latest file to be created which is a common ancestor to all revisions you wish to merge. The closer the base file is to the desired result, the fewer conflicts you will need to resolve.

  • The order in which you select files determines which file will be the base and branch file(s). The first file you select becomes the base file; the second and third (Windows only) become the branch files.

  • The items you select (project, versioned file, revision) affect the initial options that appear.

Options

There are many options you can customize for both the difference and merge functionality, including:

  • Whether or not case is ignored
  • Which colors denote differences and conflicts
  • Which font styles to use
  • Whether or not to use blank spaces and tabs
  • Whether or not to use line numbers

Many of these options, including file selection, can be saved in a configuration file for later use.

For More Information

See the Serena ChangeMan Version Manager User's Guide and the Serena ChangeMan Merge Tool online help.
